brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of this study is to determine the impact that treatment with a cellular
      concentrate derived from an individual's own fat, known as the stromal vascular fraction
      (SVF), has on the quality of life of people with multiple sclerosis (MS).  SVF contains
      components with "regenerative" properties, including stem cells that may be capable of
      ameliorating specific disease conditions.  This study is designed to evaluate quality of
      life changes in individuals with MS for up to 12 months following SVF treatment.

clinical_study.brief_title: Outcomes Data of Adipose Stem Cells to Treat Multiple Sclerosis

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Subjects scheduled for a stem cell/SVF treatment

          -  Subjects diagnosed with some form of multiple sclerosis

          -  Subjects between the ages of 18 and 65

          -  Subjects willing and able to sign informed consent

          -  Subjects willing and able to perform follow up interviews and surveys

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Subjects for whom baseline data is not available

          -  Subjects with additional major health diagnoses

          -  Subjects that are pregnant or breastfeeding

clinical_study.official_title: Autologous Adipose Stromal Vascular Fraction Outcomes Research Study

primary_outcome.measure: Change from Baseline on the Multiple Sclerosis Quality of Life Inventory (MSQLI) at 12 months

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.study_design: Observational Model: Cohort, Time Perspective: Prospective
